name: False Statement Induced Grant of Tenancy
short_description: Tenancy granted because of false statement by tenant

false_statement.made_by: Tenant or person acting at tenant's instigation

inducement.causation: False statement caused landlord to grant tenancy
inducement.test: Would not have granted tenancy if truth was known

notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice expires

evidence_required: Application form or correspondence containing false statement
Landlord's evidence they relied on the statement
Evidence showing truth (proving statement was false)
Evidence tenant knew statement was false

moderate_cases: Failed to disclose relevant information when asked
weak_cases: Information became false after tenancy started

high_probability: Statement was material to landlord's decision
Landlord can show they relied on statement
Landlord would not have granted tenancy if truth known
medium_probability: False statement proven but materiality disputed
Some reliance but other factors in decision
low_probability: Very long time since tenancy granted

red_flags: Information not directly relevant to tenancy decision
Tenant has since become model tenant
tenant_defenses: Statement was true at the time
Landlord did not rely on statement
Landlord would have granted tenancy regardless
Not reasonable to grant possession given current circumstances
Tenant has reformed and is now compliant
notes: Ground 17 is DISCRETIONARY and rarely used. Difficult to prove causation (reliance and inducement). Court considers materiality, reasonableness, and time elapsed. Often combined with Ground 12 if ongoing breach. Serious cases (forged documents, false identity) stronger than minor exaggerations.
case_law: Killick v Roberts [1991] - Statement must be material and relied upon
R v Tower Hamlets LBC ex parte Begum [1993] - Must show inducement
Shrewsbury v Blake [1998] - Test is whether tenancy would have been granted
Rushcliffe BC v Watson [1992] - Reasonableness includes time elapsed
court_considerations: Did tenant know it was false?
Was statement material to landlord's decision?
Did landlord actually rely on it?
Would landlord have granted tenancy if truth known?

materiality_test.definition: Statement is material if it would affect a reasonable landlord's decision

time_considerations.over_3_years: Weak case - tenant has established tenancy
time_considerations.note: Long-standing tenancy where tenant is compliant may make possession unreasonable
